resource.chars:
Royal Society 
Received 9 Feb 1899
30A Wimpole Street, W 
8th February 1899.
<u>To the Chairman of the Physiological Committee of the Royal Society <\u>
Sir,
I beg to return the paper by <s>Messr <\s> Professors Herdman & Boyce,
entitled “<u>Observations upon the Normal and Pathological 
“Histology and Bacteriology of the Oyster<\u>”, which has been referred 
to me for report.
<u>The first part of this paper <\u> (pp. 1-21) contains (<u>a<\u>) an historical 
introduction; (<u>b<\u>) an account of the histology of the gills; (<u>c<\u>)a 
description of a new muscle; and (<u>d<\u>) an account of the 
so-called “liver”.
The chapters on the histology of the gills and “liver” do not,
so far as I can discover, contain any result which is new: they 
do not advance our knowledge of the subject.
The new muscle is identified as a “<u>protractor pedis <\u>” which 
has changed its function in consequence of the atrophy of the foot.
The description of this muscle is new and interesting, but can 
hardly be said to mark a distinct step in knowledge. - The 
description might well be published in some technical journal.
<u>Pages 22-23 <\u> of the paper contain an essay on the on the green-
ness of oysters. In the case of “<u>huitres de Marennes <\u>”  
the authors 
confirm in detail the results obtained by Lankester in 1885,
but do not add anything of importance. They also confirm the 
old statements that some oysters are green, not from the presence 
of a colouring matter derived from <u>Navicula ostrocaria <\u>, as is the 
case in Marennes oysters, but from the presence of some other 
pigment: and they confirm the statement often made, and lately 
substantiated by Thorpe, that the pigment in question contains copper.
So far, the paper does not seem to me to contain any 
statements of importance. The remaining pages are of considerable
